question.text: With respect to Miller's experiment, which of the following condition is not applicable?

options.text: Gases in flask = <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2 </mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math>
Organic compounds obtained = Nitrogen compounds like nucleotides

solution.text: Experimental proof of theory of chemical evolution [by S.L. Miller (American scientist) in 1953]. Similar atmospheric conditions were developed on a laboratory scale - Electric discharge in a closed flask containing <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math> and water vapour at 800⁰C. Organic compounds obtained = Few amino acids were obtained.
